title.narrative: OUPUT 2.1.2: ALTERNATIVE AND INCLUSIVE EDUCATION

description.narrative: Actors in the education system are better equipped to develop quality alternative offers and innovative approaches for the education and vocational training of children, girls and boys, and adolescents outside school in the most disadvantaged regions., which contributes to Access To Quality Learning Opportunities, Access To Quality Learning Opportunities (Covid), Cross-Sectoral - Conflict Prevention, Fragility And Peacebuilding, Cross-Sectoral - Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement (Covid), Operations Support To Programme Delivery. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Digital Transformation, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, Innovation, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Risk-Informed Humanitarian And Development Nexus Programming, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2025, girls and boys of school age (4â€“19 years), particularly the most disadvantaged, have access to quality education and training and acquire basic skills.

Technical assistance - Equitable access to quality education

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Actors in the education system are better equipped to develop quality alternative offers and innovative approaches for theeducation and vocational training of children, girls and boys, and adolescents outside school in the most disadvantaged regions.

description.narrative: In 2021 the CO continued to promote equitable access to education through support for implementation of the national strategy for integrating children from Islamic education structures in the formal education system, as well as for ‘bridging’ classes and promoting girls’ access to technical and vocational training (TEVT). As a result, 102,073 children in Islamic schools were integrated in the official education system, 8,419 children were integrated through bridge classes and 616 girls benefitted from TVET. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:13/01/2022
